(a) It shall be unlawful for any person to: (1) Negligently and without authority to injure or destroy any meter, pipe, conduit, wire, line, post, lamp or other apparatus belonging to the city or a company engaged in the manufacture or sale of electricity, gas, water, sewer, telephone or other public services; (2) Negligently and without authority to prevent a meter from properly registering the quantity of such service supplied; (3) In any way to interfere with the proper action of the city or such company; (4) Negligently to divert any services of the city or such company; or (5) Otherwise negligently and without authority to use or cause to be used, without the consent of the city or such company any service manufactured, sold or distributed by the city or such company. (b) Where there is no evidence to the contrary, the person performing any of the illegal acts set forth in subsection (a) of this section and the person who with knowledge of such violation receives the benefit of such service without proper charge as a result of the improper action shall be presumed to be responsible for the act of tampering or diversion. (c) It shall be unlawful for any person intentionally and without authority to injure or destroy any traffic-control equipment, sign, vehicle, recreation equipment, recreation property, lock, padlock, building or other such property belonging to the city. (Code 1992, § 11-3; Ord. No. 87-3, 7-7-1987) State Law reference— Damaging, injuring or interfering with property of public utility companies, municipalities or political subdivisions, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25. Sec. 36-83. - Theft or destruction of road and traffic signs. It shall be illegal for any person to steal, vandalize, destroy or otherwise damage any public road or traffic sign in the city. Secs. 36-84—36-109. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - MINORS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 36-110—36-131. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - CURFEW
Sec. 36-132. - Purposes. The city council has determined that: (1) Persons under the age of 18 are particularly susceptible by their lack of maturity and experience to participate in unlawful activity and to be victims of older perpetrators of crime. (2) There has been a significant breakdown in the supervision and guidance normally provided by parents for minors resulting in an increase in the crimes, substance abuse, and school dropout rates, juvenile pregnancy, and other illicit behavior. (3) The city has an obligation to provide for the protection of minors from each other and from other persons, for the enforcement of parental control over and responsibility for children, for the protection of the general public, and for the reduction of the incidence of juvenile criminal activities which are not easily controlled by existing laws and ordinances. (4) A curfew for those under the age of 16 years will be in the interest of the public health, safety, and general welfare and will help attain the foregoing objectives and diminish the undesirable impact of such conduct on the citizens of the city and will promote the public good, safety and welfare. (5) Parental responsibility for the whereabouts of children is the accepted norm and legal sanctions to enforce such responsibility have had demonstrated effectiveness in many cities. (6) A curfew will increase parental responsibility for minors within their control and decrease minor delinquency. Sec. 36-133. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Emergency errand means a mission that results from an unforeseen combination of circumstances that call for immediate action. The term "emergency errand" includes, but is not limited to, a fire, a natural disaster, or automobile accident, or any situation requiring immediate action to prevent serious bodily injury or loss of life. Minor means any unemancipated person under the age of 16 years. Public place means any place to which the public has access and includes, but is not limited to, streets, highways, alleys or rights-of-way, to include sidewalks, parks, playgrounds, malls, or other places or buildings open to the public; any cemeteries, schoolyards, bodies of water or watercourses; any privately or publicly owned places of amusement, entertainment or public accommodation, including parking lots; and any vacant lot or land. Sec. 36-134. - Hours; prohibited conduct. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 18 years to walk, loiter, idle, wander, stroll or play or to be present in or upon the public streets, highways, roads, alleys, parks, playgrounds or other grounds, public places and public buildings, places of amusement and entertainment, vacant lots or other such places on Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday of every week between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. of the following day, official city time, and on Friday and Saturday of every week between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. of the following day, official city time; provided, however, that the provisions of this section do not apply to a minor accompanied by his parent or other adult person having the care and custody of the minor at that time, or where the minor is upon an emergency errand or legitimate business directed in writing, dated and signed by his parents, guardian or adult person having custody of the minor. (b) Any minor under the age of 18 years who shall do any of the acts prohibited by subsection (a) of this section shall, upon request, furnish to the officers his name and address and that of his parents or guardian or person having custody and care of such minor and then be directed by any officer of the police department to return to his dwelling place or residence. Upon the failure or refusal of such minor to return forthwith, he shall be turned over to the appropriate court for disposition. (Code 1992, § 11-13(a), (b); Ord. of 10-7-1969, § 4) Sec. 36-135. - Parental responsibility. (a) It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of a minor under the age of 18 years to allow, permit, make possible, tolerate or condone such minor to walk, loiter, idle, wander, stroll, play or to be present in or upon the public streets, highways, roads, alleys, parks, playgrounds or other grounds, public places and public buildings, places of amusement and entertainment, vacant lots or other unsupervised places on Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday of every week between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. of the following day, official city time, and on Friday and Saturday of every week between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. of the following day, official city time. (b) The parent or guardian or person having the care and custody of a minor under the age of 18 years, which minor shall have failed to return forthwith to his dwelling place or residence after having been requested to do so by an officer of the police department, shall, upon proof that such parent or guardian or person having custody or care of the minor has permitted the minor to do any of the acts prohibited to minors by this section, be deemed guilty of an offense, and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in section 1-15. (Code 1992, § 11-13(c), (d); Ord. of 10-7-1969, § 4) Sec. 36-136. - Exceptions; defenses. It is an exception to, and shall be an affirmative defense to any charge of violations of the terms of this article, if the minor is involved in any of the following activities: (1) Emergency errand. The minor is upon an emergency errand directed by his parent, guardian, or other adult person 21 years of age or older having the lawful care and custody of the minor; (2) School activity. The minor is returning directly home from a school activity; (3) Employment. The minor is traveling to, or returning directly home from, lawful employment that makes it necessary to be in the places referenced in section 36-135 during the proscribed period of time; (4) Constitutional rights. The minor is attending or traveling directly to or from an activity involving the exercise of First Amendment rights of free speech, freedom of assembly, or free exercise of religion; (5) Travel. The minor is engaged in interstate and intrastate vehicular travel through the city with parental consent; (6) Residence. The minor is on the sidewalk adjoining the property where the minor resides or on the property where the minor resides or on either side of or across the street from the property where the minor resides and the adult or the owner or resident of that property has given permission for the minor to be there; and (7) Marriage. The minor is married or has been married pursuant to state law.

div.head: Chapter 38 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1]
div.p: (RESERVED) Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— City and county recreation systems, O.C.G.A. § 36-64-1 et seq.; gifts of public parks or pleasure grounds to municipality, O.C.G.A. § 36-37-1; park and recreation boards, O.C.G.A. § 36-64-5; establishment of city and county supervised recreation, O.C.G.A. § 36-64-3; political subdivisions to have environmental testing on property acquired for park or recreational area, O.C.G.A. § 36-80-18.

div.head: Chapter 40 - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Peddlers and itinerant traders, O.C.G.A. § 43-32-1 et seq.; municipal and county ordinances for issuance of permits to charitable organizations for solicitation of contributions on streets and highways, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-97.1; charitable solicitations, O.C.G.A. § 43-17-1 et seq.; transient merchants, O.C.G.A. § 43-46-1.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 40-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Itinerant merchant means any person regardless of whether as owner, agent, consignee or employee, and regardless of whether a resident of the city, who engages in a temporary business of selling and delivering goods, wares, and merchandise within the city, and who, in furtherance of such purpose, hires, leases, uses, or occupies any building, structure, motor vehicle, tent, railroad box car, boat, or public room in any hotel, lodginghouse, apartment, or shop within the city for the exhibition and sale of such goods, wares, and merchandise, either privately or at public auction. Peddler means any person, regardless of whether a resident of the city, traveling by foot, wagon, automotive vehicle, or any other type of conveyance from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, carrying, conveying, or transporting goods, wares, merchandise, meats, fish, vegetables, fruits, garden produce, farm products, or provisions who offers and exposes the same for sale, or who, without traveling from place to place, sells or offers the same for sale from a wagon, automotive vehicle, railroad car, or other vehicle or conveyance. Secs. 40-2—40-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PEDDLERS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 40-21. - Exemptions. None of the provisions of this article shall extend to persons selling the agricultural products of any state, nor to persons selling agricultural implements, nor to persons engaged in the manufacturing and selling of jugs and flower pots, nor to persons working with official nonprofit organizations. (Code 1992, § 6-202; Ord. of 5-3-1983, § VII) Sec. 40-22. - Prohibited locations. No peddler or itinerant merchant shall be permitted to locate any such business enterprise inthe following locations: (1) Upon any lot located on Watson Boulevard from 2764 Watson Boulevard on the east and to Margie Drive on the west. (2) Upon any lot located on Houston Lake Boulevard on the south to Brantley Road on the north. (3) Upon any lot located on Carl Vinson Parkway from Elberta Road to Dunbar Road. (4) Upon any location on Collins Avenue from Watson Boulevard on the south to Thomson Avenue on the north. (5) Such other locations as are specified from time to time by the city council. (Code 1992, § 6-202; Ord. of 5-3-1983, § IV) Sec. 40-23. - Property lease required for location. No peddler or itinerant merchant shall be permitted to operate his business without proof of a written lease from the owner of the property upon which the peddler business is to be operated. (Code 1992, § 6-203; Ord. of 5-3-1983, § V) Sec. 40-24. - Noise restrictions. No licensee under this article, nor anyone in his behalf, shall shout, make any outcry, blow a horn, ring a bell, or use any other sound device including any loud-speaking radio or amplifying system upon any of the streets, alleys, parks, or other public places of the city or upon any private premises in the city where sound of sufficient volume is emitted or produced therefrom capable of being plainly heard upon the streets, avenues, alleys, parks, or other public places for the purpose of attracting attention to any goods, wares, or merchandise that the licensee proposes to sell. Secs. 40-25—40-51. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - LICENSE
Sec. 40-52. - Required; fee. All peddlers and itinerant merchants selling goods or services in the city shall first obtain a license as provided in this division. The license fee for peddlers and itinerant merchants shall be as set out in the city fee schedule in chapter 22, to be paid upon application by each person desiring to engage in such business. (Code 1992, § 6-221; Ord. of 5-3-1983, § I) Sec. 40-53. - Application. At the time of making license application each peddler shall furnish evidence of his good character which shall include among other things his social security number, his places of residence for the previous 12 months, a copy of his driver's license, and two passport-type pictures. If the license is granted one of the pictures must be attached to the license which license must be carried on the person of the peddler at all times. (Code 1992, § 6-222; Ord. of 5-3-1983, § II) Sec. 40-54. - Oath. Each peddler shall take and subscribe before the city clerk this oath: "I swear that I will use this license in no city other than Centerville, that I will not suffer any person to use it in my name, and that I am a citizen of the United States. So help me God." (Code 1992, § 6-223; Ord. of 5-3-1983, § III) Sec. 40-55. - Duty to exhibit. All persons obtaining a license under the provisions of this article shall be required to exhibit such license at the request of any citizen. Secs. 40-56—40-83. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - CHARITABLE SOLICITORS
Sec. 40-84. - Registration required. Any person who wishes to solicit donations or contributions for, or to sell any insignia or novelty on the streets of the city on behalf of, or under the sponsorship of, any charitable, religious, social, patriotic, or civic club or organization shall be required to register such solicitation or sale with the city clerk and the chief of police at least 48 hours in advance of such event and to obtain a permit therefor. Sec. 40-85. - Application for permit. (a) The permit required by this article shall be in writing, shall be signed by the chief officer of the club or organization, and shall contain the following information: (1) The name and object of the charitable, religious, social, patriotic, or civic club or organization conducting or sponsoring the solicitation or sale to which the registration relates; (2) The day on which the solicitation or sale will take place; (3) The object for which the funds to be derived from the solicitation or sale will be utilized; and (4) The name and address of the chief officer of the club or organization conducting or sponsoring the solicitation or sale. (b) The application shall be accompanied by a permit fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule in chapter 22. Sec. 40-86. - Exemptions. This article shall not apply to any locally established organization or church operated exclusively for charitable or religious purposes if the solicitations are in the form of collections or contributions at the regular assemblies of any such organization or church. Sec. 40-87. - Duty to exhibit registration. Charitable solicitors shall be required to exhibit their permit at the request of any citizen. Sec. 40-88. - Prohibited acts. It shall be unlawful for any person to execute an application for permit under this article that contains any false statement, and it shall be unlawful for any person to solicit donations or contributions or sell any insignia or novelty on the streets of the city purportedly in behalf of, or under the sponsorship of, any charitable, religious, social, patriotic, or civic club or organization that does not in fact exist.

div.head: Chapter 42 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Downtown development authorities, O.C.G.A. § 36-42-1 et seq.; municipal business improvement districts, O.C.G.A. § 36-43-1 et seq.; redevelopment authority of municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 36-44-1 city and county development authorities, O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1 et seq.; county and municipal urban development, O.C.G.A. § 36-61-1 et seq.; city and county zoning procedures, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-1 et seq.; local zoning proposal review procedures, O.C.G.A. § 36-67-1 et seq.; conflicts of interest in zoning actions, O.C.G.A. § 36-67A-1 et seq.; coordinated and comprehensive planning and service delivery by counties and municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 36-70-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 42-1. - Adoption of comprehensive plan. The city's comprehensive plan, dated January 2,2007, as amended from time to time by the city council, is incorporated as though fully set forth in this chapter. Secs. 42-2—42-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - MIDDLE GEORGIA REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION
Sec. 42-21. - Name designated. The Middle Georgia Area Planning Commission shall henceforth be known as the Middle Georgia Regional Development Commission. (Code 1992, § 12-26; Ord. of 1-2-1973, § 1) Sec. 42-22. - Membership. The Middle Georgia Regional Development Commission by bylaw shall provide for its membership and for the selection of representatives by the member governments, subject, of course, to the requirements and limitations of this article and of applicable state law. Members shall serve without compensation. (Code 1992, § 12-27; Ord. of 1-2-1973, § 2) Sec. 42-23. - Organization. The Middle Georgia Regional Development Commission is hereby authorized to elect its officers and manage its affairs in accordance with its bylaws, subject, of course, to the requirements and limitations of this article and of applicable state law. (Code 1992, § 12-28; Ord. of 1-2-1973, § 3) Sec. 42-24. - Powers, duties. The Middle Georgia Regional Development Commission shall be a joint planning commission as defined in and with all of the powers, duties and obligations of a joint planning commission set forth in that certain Act approved March 13, 1957, (1957 Ga. Laws (Act No. 358, p. 420 et seq.), as heretofore or hereafter amended, and an area planning and development commission as defined in and with all of the powers, duties, and obligations of an area planning and development commission set forth in that certain Act approved March 18, 1970, (1970 Ga. Laws (Act No. 1066, p. 321 et seq.), as heretofore or hereafter amended. The Middle Georgia Regional Development Commission shall also have all the powers, duties and obligations of a joint planning commission and area planning and development commission set forth in any other law of general application pertaining to joint planning commissions and area planning and development commissions. (Code 1992, § 12-29; Ord. of 1-2-1973, § 4) Sec. 42-25. - Initial bylaws approved. The initial bylaws of the Middle Georgia Regional Development Commission are on file in the city clerk's office where they are available for reference and review. (Code 1992, § 12-30; Ord. of 1-2-1973, § 5) Sec. 42-26. - Advisory capacity. The Middle Georgia Regional Development Commission shall continue to act in an advisory capacity only, and any plan, or part thereof, or amendment, extension or addition thereto, adopted by the center shall constitute a recommendation only and shall have no binding effect on the member governments in implementing any plans and/or zoning laws. (Code 1992, § 12-31; Ord. of 1-2-1973, § 7) Sec. 42-27. - No effect on local planning and zoning commission. This chapter shall not affect the present or future powers and duties granted to any existing local planning and zoning commission or in any way affect the future creation of any local planning and zoning commission. (Code 1992, § 12-32; Ord. of 1-2-1973, § 8)

div.head: Chapter 44 - SECONDHAND GOODS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Junk dealers, O.C.G.A. § 43-22-1; pawnbrokers generally, O.C.G.A. § 44-12-130 et seq.; local regulation of pawnbrokers, O.C.G.A. §§ 44-12-135, 44-12-136.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 44-1—44-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PAWNBROKERS
Sec. 44-19. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Pawnbroker means any person engaged in whole or in part in the business of lending money on the security of pledged goods, or in the business of purchasing tangible personal property on the condition that it may be redeemed or repurchased by the seller for a fixed price within a fixed period of time, or in the business of purchasing tangible personal property from persons or sources other than manufacturers or licensed dealers as a part of or in conjunction with the business activities described in O.C.G.A. §§ 44-12-130 et seq., which sections are incorporated herein by reference thereto. (Code 1992, § 6-3(a); Ord. No. 94-20, 12-27-1994; Ord. No. 95-3, 4-4-1995) Sec. 44-20. - Activities constituting pawn business. Any person who purchases jewelry, guns, pistols, firearms, weapons, rifles, household effects or other items of personal property and at the time thereof gives the seller the privilege of redeeming the property thereafter shall be deemed and held to be a pawnbroker within the intent and meaning of this article. (Code 1992, § 6-3(b); Ord. No. 94-20, 12-27-1994; Ord. No. 95-3, 4-4-1995) Sec. 44-21. - License required; fee; occupation taxes. No person shall operate a pawnbroker business in the city unless he obtains a business in the manner provided in chapter 12 and pays the administrative and license fee provided in the city fee schedule in chapter 22. Pawnbrokers shall be subject to city occupation taxes in the same manner as all other businesses operating in the city. (Code 1992, § 6-3; Ord. No. 94-20, 12-27-1994; Ord. No. 95-3, 4-4-1995) Sec. 44-22. - Qualifications for licensure. (a) All applicants for a pawnbroker's license must be of good character, and all managers, clerks or other employees shall be of like character or the application will not be considered. Prior to obtaining a license a certificate must be obtained from the chief of police that the applicant and his agents have no record of a criminal offense (minor traffic offense excluded) within the previous seven years. (b) No applicant for a license or an agent therefor who has a criminal record (except minor traffic offenses) shall be granted a license. The plea of nolo contendere and the forfeiture of bond or collateral shall be considered a conviction for the purposes of this section. Additionally, no applicant who has been convicted of violating any ordinance of the city or any law or regulation of the state or any political subdivision thereof, governing the sale of any alcoholic beverage shall be granted a license. (Code 1992, § 6-3(c), (d); Ord. No. 94-20, 12-27-1994; Ord. No. 95-3, 4-4-1995) Sec. 44-23. - Factors considered in determining good moral character. Ascertainable standards of good moral character of applicant which may be considered by the city council in deciding if a license will be issued include, but are not limited to, the following: (1) Present and prior compliance with city ordinances. (2) Prior supervision over employees and customers. (3) Truthfulness in submitted application. (4) Criminal and civil court records. (5) Employment history. (6) Credit reports. (Code 1992, § 6-3(f); Ord. No. 94-20, 12-27-1994; Ord. No. 95-3, 4-4-1995) Sec. 44-24. - Renewal. Except as provided in section 44-25, all pawnbroker licenses in this section may be renewed by payment of the required fees provided: (1) Applications for renewal of existing licenses are made in person by the applicants at the office of the city clerk. Such license fee shall be payable January 1 of each year and shall be delinquent if not paid by April 1 of each year; (2) The licensee and location are the same; (3) The licensee's circumstances would enable him to qualify for a license if the renewal was a new application; and (4) The licensee is still in compliance with the requirements of state and municipal laws and regulations pertaining to the original issuance of the license and pertaining to the operation of the business under the license at the time of application for renewal. (Code 1992, § 6-3(g)(1)—(4); Ord. No. 94-20, 12-27-1994; Ord. No. 95-3, 4-4-1995) Sec. 44-25. - Effect of complaint on renewal; complaint procedure. If a complaint is received as to the licensee's alleged violation of state or municipal law or regulation before December 31 of the licensed year or 30 days after the application for renewal is received whichever date is later, the license shall not be renewed, but shall be referred to the city council for decision as to whether renewal shall be granted as follows: (1) The city council shall conduct a hearing after giving the licensee reasonable notice of the time and place of such hearing, as well as the purpose thereof. (2) The licensee may remain open for business until a decision by the city council is made and shall have a period of three days following that decision in which to pay the required fees if the decision of city council is to permit renewal of the license. (Code 1992, § 6-3(g)(5); Ord. No. 94-20, 12-27-1994; Ord. No. 95-3, 4-4-1995) Sec. 44-26. - Inspections. Each pawnbroker shall hold and maintain his business subject to visitation and inspection by an authorized law enforcement officer. (Code 1992, § 6-3(i); Ord. No. 94-20, 12-27-1994; Ord. No. 95-3, 4-4-1995) Sec. 44-27. - Effect of refusal to permit inspection. (a) If any pawnbroker and any clerk, agent or employee of such pawnbroker shall refuse to allow any duly authorized law enforcement officer who is certified by the state peace officer standards and training council or who is a federal officer to inspect his permanent record book or any goods in his possession during the ordinary hours of business or at any reasonable time shall be subject to immediate closure by the governing authority of the city. (b) Upon receipt by the mayor or mayor pro tem of notice by an authorized inspection officer that a reasonable inspection has been refused by the pawnbroker or his agent, the license of the pawnbroker shall be suspended. (c) The pawnbroker shall have ten days after suspension notice by the chief of police or his designee to request a hearing before the governing authority of the city to show cause why the license should not be suspended. If application for hearing to show cause is filed with the clerk of the city within ten days from the notice of suspension the license shall not be suspended until after the hearing. (d) If the application is not filed with the clerk of the city within ten days from the notice of suspension, the suspension shall begin ten days from the date of the notice of suspension. (Code 1992, § 6-3(i); Ord. No. 94-20, 12-27-1994; Ord. No. 95-3, 4-4-1995) Sec. 44-28. - Duty to submit report to police department. Each person holding a pawnbroker license in the city or conducting a pawnbroking business in the city, shall make a report to the chief of police of the city before 10:00 a.m., Monday through Saturday of every article or thing whether such purchase be conditional or with the privilege of redeeming on the part of the seller or any other pawnbroker type transaction which occurred on the previous day and such report shall specify the article or thing involved in the transaction giving a full description thereof, such as a number, mark and other details as will make identification of such article or thing clear or positive. Monday's report shall include Saturday and Sunday. (Code 1992, § 6-3(h); Ord. No. 94-20, 12-27-1994; Ord. No. 95-3, 4-4-1995) Secs. 44-29—44-59. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - JUNK DEALERS AND JUNKYARDS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Junk dealers, O.C.G.A. § 43-22-1.
Sec. 44-60. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Auto wrecking establishment means junkyard. Automobile body shop means automotive repair garage. Automotive repair garage means a business establishment involving maintenance, repair, conversion and other such services on cars, trucks, boats, motorcycles, recreational vehicles, and mobile/manufactured homes, typically including vehicle storage and incidental sales of parts, also referred to as automotive services. Business premises or premises means the area of a junkyard as described in a junk dealer's license or application for license, as provided for in this article. Junk means old iron, steel, brass, copper, tin, lead, or other base metals; old cordage, ropes, rags, fibers, or fabrics; old rubber; old bottles or other glass; bones; wastepaper and other waste or discarded material which might be prepared to be used again in some form; and motor vehicles, no longer used as such, to be used for scrap metal or stripping of parts. The term "junk" does not include materials or objects accumulated by a person as byproducts, waste, or scraps from the operation of his own business, or materials or objects held and used by a manufacturer as an integral part of his own manufacturing processes. Junk dealer means a person who operates a junkyard, as defined in this section, within the city. Junkyard means a yard, lot, or place, covered or uncovered, outdoors or in an enclosed building, containing junk as defined in this section, upon which occurs one or more acts of buying, keeping, dismantling, processing, selling, or offering for sale any such junk, in whole units or by pans, for a business or commercial purpose, whether or not the proceeds from such acts are to be used for charity. Sec. 44-61. - License; fee; occupation tax. No person shall operate as a junk dealer or junkyard in the city unless he obtains a business in the manner provided in chapter 12 and pays the administrative and license fee provided in the city fee schedule in chapter 22. Junk dealers and junkyards shall be subject to city occupation taxes in the same manner as all other businesses operating in the city. Sec. 44-62. - Regulations. The following general operating requirements shall apply to all junk dealers licensed in accordance with the provisions of this article: (1) The junkyard, together with things kept therein, shall at all times be maintained in a sanitary condition. (2) No space not covered by the license shall be used in the licensed business. (3) No water shall be allowed to stand in any place on the premises in such manner as to afford a breeding place for mosquitoes. (4) No weeds shall be permitted to attain a height of more than four inches. (5) No garbage or other waste liable to give off a foul odor or attract vermin shall be kept on the premises; nor shall any refuse of any kind be kept on the premises, unless such refuse is junk as defined herein and is in use in the licensed business. (6) No junk shall be allowed to rest upon or protrude over any public street, walkway, or curb, or become scattered or blown off the business premises. (7) Junk shall be stored in piles not exceeding ten feet in height and shall be arranged so as to permit easy access to all such junk for firefighting purposes. (8) No combustible material of any kind not necessary or beneficial to the licensed business shall be kept on the premises; nor shall the premises be allowed to become a fire hazard. (9) Gasoline and oil shall be removed from any scrapped engines or vehicles on the premises. (10) No junk or other material shall be burned on the premises in any incinerator not meeting the requirements of the building code; and no junk or other material shall be burned on the premises in the open except in accordance with the provisions of this Code. (11) No noisy processing of junk or other noisy activity shall be carried on in connection with the licensed business or any Sunday, Christmas, Thanksgiving, or at any time between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. (12) The area on the premises where junk is kept (other than indoors) shall be enclosed, except for entrances and exits, with a solid, vertical wall or fence of a minimum height of eight feet measured from ground level. The fence or wall shall not contain any poster or advertising of any kind as may be permitted under chapter 46, pertaining to signs. (13) Entrances and exits shall not be wider or more numerous than reasonably necessary for the conduct of the licensed business. (14) No junkyard shall be allowed to become a nuisance nor shall any junkyard be operated in such manner as to become injurious to the health, safety, or welfare of the community or of any residents close by. Sec. 44-63. - Recordkeeping. Each acquisition of junk shall be recorded in a permanent type register kept on the business premises, giving the name and residence address of the person from whom the acquisition was made, a description of the junk acquired, and the date of the transaction. Such data shall be held available for inspection by any law enforcement officer. Sec. 44-64. - Minors. No junk dealer shall have any business dealings as a junk dealer with a minor, nor shall a junk dealer's license be issued to a minor, nor shall a junk dealer employ a minor to assist him in his business. Sec. 44-65. - Stolen goods. Every junk dealer who shall receive or be in possession of any goods, articles, or things of value which may have been lost or stolen shall upon demand produce such article or thing to any member of the police department for examination. Sec. 44-66. - Vehicles. Every vehicle used by a junk dealer in the conduct of his business shall bear thereon in legible characters the name and address of the owner and proprietor thereof. Secs. 44-67—44-69. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - PRECIOUS METALS AND GEM DEALERS
Sec. 44-70. - Definitions. As used in this article, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them in this section: Precious gems means any precious or semi-precious stone, including but not limited to, diamond, ruby, sapphire or emerald which is cut and polished. Precious metals means gold, silver or platinum or any alleged alloy containing gold, silver or platinum. Precious metals and gems dealer means any person, partnership, sole proprietorship, corporation, association or other entity engaged in, either exclusively or incidentally to or in connection with other business, the business of purchasing, selling, bartering or acquiring in trade any precious metals or gems from persons or sources other than manufacturers or licensed dealers. (Ord. No. 2014-3, 8-5-2014) Sec. 44-71. - License application; exemption. (a) No person shall engage in business as a precious metals dealer in the city except under a license granted by the city. (b) All applications shall be made to the city clerk and shall be accompanied by an application fee of $150.00. All applications shall be in writing upon a form supplied to by the city clerk. (c) The application for the license shall state the name and address of the applicant, the street and number at which the applicant proposes to operate such business and the names and addresses of all persons having a financial interest in such business. Every person having an ownership interest in the business carried on by a precious metals dealer and all employees engaged in said business shall be at least 18 years of age. The application shall contain an accurate description of the premises upon which the business is to be conducted, along with the zoning classification therefor and such other information as may be required. (d) The application for license shall list all convictions, guilty pleas or pleas of nolo contender by or against the applicant(s) for a period of five years preceding the date of such application for such violation of any felony of any state or of the United States, together with a waiver sufficient to authorize investigation of the criminal record of the applicant, if any. All applicants shall swear and affirm that the information disclosed in the application is true and correct. (e) Any person who holds a valid pawnbroker license pursuant to article II of this chapter shall be exempt from the license requirements of this article, but shall comply with the requirements of sections 44-74 through 44-79 of this article if said license holder meets the definition of a "precious metals and gems dealer" as defined herein. (Ord. No. 2014-3, 8-5-2014) Sec. 44-72. - License, issuance. (a) No license shall be granted pursuant to this article to any applicant who has been convicted, pled guilty or pled nolo contender to any felony as described in subsection 44-71(d) above. Moreover, no license shall be issued to any applicant who is not a citizen of the United States or an alien lawfully admitted to be a permanent resident of the United States. (b) No license shall be granted to any person until all requirements of this chapter have been met and all amounts associated with the issuance of this license have been paid. No license shall be granted if the applicant has any outstanding or delinquent amounts for taxes, licenses, past due utilities or fees of any kind due the city. (c) All applications for license shall be granted or denied within 60 days of a completed application. Any application not granted upon by the city clerk's office within said period shall be deemed denied. (d) Any precious metals or gems dealer already engaging in such business prior to the adoption of this article shall file an application, in accordance with the terms of this article by November 1, 2014. If the mayor and council determine that any such application filed pursuant to this subsection should be denied, the applicant may continue to operate his/her business for a period of 30 days following the date on which the application is denied; provided, however, that at all times during which such applicant continues to operate his/her business he/she shall be subject to and comply with all the provisions of this article. (Ord. No. 2014-3, 8-5-2014) Sec. 44-73. - Revocation; suspension. Any person failing to comply with the provisions of this article or such other ordinances and regulations as may be adopted by the governing authority for the conduct of the business of a precious metals and/or gems dealer shall be subject to having the license to conduct such business revoked or suspended for a definite period of time at the discretion of the governing authority, after proper notice and hearing. Such forfeiture and suspension shall result from conviction or violation of any provision of this article or any other ordinance or regulation governing the conduct of the business for which such license shall have been issued. The governing authority may also consider as grounds for revocation or suspension a failure of the license application to contain any record of convictions required by section 44-71 of this article. (Ord. No. 2014-3, 8-5-2014) Sec. 44-74. - Record of transactions; inspection by police. (a) All precious metals and gems dealers shall keep books, in permanent form, wherein shall be entered, in English and in legible form, an accurate, detailed description of all precious metals and gems sold to them. Such description shall include: (1) The name of the maker of the article; (2) Any identifying mark or number and a description of the kind of material of which it is made so that such article can be reasonably and definitely identified; (3) A photograph of the item, made at the time and place of purchase, (which photograph shall be attached to the page whereon the corresponding entry is made); (4) The name, address and age of the person by whom such article was deposited or sold as verified by a valid, government-issued picture identification of the seller; (5) The date and hour the transaction was made; (6) A photograph or copy of the identification of the seller, made at the time and place of purchase, (which photograph shall be attached to the page whereon the corresponding entry is made); and (7) The signature of the seller. (b) The permanent record book shall be maintained for each purchase of precious metals and/or gems for a period of three years from the date of purchase of the last entry in said record book. Entries shall appear chronologically and shall be signed, in ink, by the purchaser at the end of each complete entry. No blank lines may be left between the entries. No obliterations, alterations or erasures may be made. Corrections shall be made by drawing a line of ink through the entry without destroying its legibility. Such book and the articles pledged or sold shall at all times be subject to inspection and examination by the police. Upon refusal of the proprietors at any time to submit their shops to a thorough inspection by the police, the shops shall be immediately closed and the permit and license revoked. (Ord. No. 2014-3, 8-5-2014) Sec. 44-75. - Holding period for goods. Any precious metals and gems dealer or person operating under a precious metals and gems dealers license who takes or buys precious metals or gems, taking full title thereto, shall hold unaltered, such goods so taken or purchased for at least ten days before disposing of the same by sale, transfer, shipment or otherwise. (Ord. No. 2014-3, 8-5-2014) Sec. 44-76. - Reports of transactions. Every precious metals and gems dealers shall complete a weekly report, in such form as may be prescribed by the chief of police, of all precious metals or gems taken or bought by him during the preceding seven-day (Monday—Sunday) period. Such report shall show the name and address of the precious metals and gems dealer; the time of each transaction; the serial number, if any, on the item; the amount paid, pledged, or advanced; a full description of the article, including the kind, style, material, color, design, kind and number of stones in jewelry and all identifying names, marks and numbers; along with a photograph of each article; and a description of the person selling, including the name, address, race, sex, weight and height and such other information as may be required by the chief of police. The form required by this section shall be hand delivered or transmitted electronically, along with the required photographs, to the Centerville Police Department each Monday morning by 10:00 a.m. (Ord. No. 2014-3, 8-5-2014) Sec. 44-77. - Purchases from minors. It shall be unlawful for any precious metals and gems dealer, or his or her agents or employees to receive or purchase any precious metals or gems of any character or description from any person who is less than 18 years of age. Any precious metals or gems dealer or his or her agents or employees shall have the burden of requiring identification sufficient to show that any person making a sale is not less than 18 years of age. (Ord. No. 2014-3, 8-5-2014) Sec. 44-78. - Hours of operation. The hours within which precious metals or gems dealers may remain open shall be from 9:00 a.m. until 9:00 p.m. (Ord. No. 2014-3, 8-5-2014) Sec. 44-79. - Violations and penalties. The performance of any act prohibited by any section or provision of this article, or the failure to perform any act required thereby, shall constitute a violation and an offense hereunder and any person found guilty in the city court of a violation of any section or provision of this article shall be punished as provided in section 22-1 of this Code. (Ord. No. 2014-3, 8-5-2014) Secs. 44-80—44-100. - Reserved.

div.head: Chapter 46 - SIGNS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Control of signs and signals, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-50 et seq.; placement of posters, signs and advertisements on public or private property; permission and limitations, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-58; limitations on signs identifying or advertising sale of distilled spirits, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-3; restrictions on certain signs providing information in the interest of the traveling public and multiple message signs, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-75.
Sec. 46-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Aggregate sign area means the combined sign area of all signs of a particular category on a single parcel. For example the aggregate sign area of all freestanding signs on a parcel is the sum total of the sign areas of all freestanding signs on such parcel. Animated sign means a sign that has moving parts or includes action, motion, or color changes, or the optical illusion of action, motion, or color changes, including signs using electronic ink, signs set in motion by movement of the atmosphere, or made up of a series of sections that turn, including any type of screen using animated or scrolling displays such as an LED (light emitting diode) screen or any other type of video display, even if the message is stationary. Banner means a sign of fabric, thin plastic or similar lightweight material that is mounted to a pole or a building at one or more edges. Flags shall not be considered banners. Beacon means a stationary or evolving light which flashes or projects illumination, single color or multicolored, in any manner which is intended to attract or divert attention; except, however, this term is not intended to include any kind of lighting device which is required or necessary under the safety regulations described by the Federal Aviation Administration or similar agencies. Bench sign means any bench or structure whose primary purpose is for sitting upon which a message is displayed. Billboard means a freestanding sign with a display surface area of more than 300 square feet. Business park means one or more buildings located on property in common ownership, management or operation, units of which are owned, leased or rented primarily for office, institutional or light industrial purposes. Changeable copy sign means a sign that is capable of changing the position or format of word messages or other displays on the sign face or change the visible display of words, numbers, symbols and graphics by the use of a matrix of electric lamps, movable discs, movable panels, light apertures or other methods, provided these changes are actuated by either a control mechanism or manually on the face of the sign. Tri-vision signs and LED signs are specifically excluded from the definition of the term "changeable copy sign." Display surface area. See Sign face. District or zoning district means a section of the incorporated area of the city for which the then effective zoning ordinance governing the use of buildings and land is uniform for each class of use permitted therein. Erect means to build, construct, attach, hang, place, suspend, or affix, and shall also include the painting of wall and window signs. Enforcement officer means the code enforcement officer or building inspector and the streets and utilities department superintendent or his qualified designee. Flag means a sign consisting of any fabric containing distinctive colors, patterns, logos or symbols, used as a symbol of a government or any other entity or organization. Freestanding sign means a sign which is attached to or part of a completely self-supporting structure. The supporting structure shall be set firmly in or below the ground surface and shall not be attached to any building or any other structure, whether portable or stationary. Illuminated sign means any sign or portion thereof which is illuminated by artificial light, either from an interior or exterior source, including outline, reflective or phosphorescent light, whether or not the source of light is directly affixed as part of the sign, and shall also include signs with reflectors that depend upon sunlight or automobile headlights for an image. Illuminated, external, means illumination so arranged that the light source is external to the sign and directed toward the sign. Illuminated, internal, means illumination so arranged that the light is contained behind the face of the sign and no lighting source is directly visible exterior to the sign. Incidental sign means a sign of no more than two square feet that serves the purpose of guiding safe traffic movements onto, from or on property, and without which there is an increased risk of incompatible traffic movements or obstructions. Examples of incidental signs include, but are not limited to, "stop," "no parking," "entrance," "loading zone" and other similar traffic related directives. Joint sign means a sign which serves as a common or collective sign for a group of persons or businesses operating on the same parcel (e.g., shopping center, office complex, etc.). Lease means an agreement by which a property owner conveys, usually for a specified rent, to other persons, permission to erect and maintain a sign upon his property. LED sign means any sign or portion thereof that uses light emitting diode technology or other similar semiconductor technology to produce an illuminated image, picture, or message of any kind whether the image, picture, or message is moving or stationary. This type of sign includes any sign that uses LED technology of any kind, whether conventional (using discrete LEDs), surface mounted (otherwise known as individually mounted LEDs), transmissive, organic light emitting diodes (OLED), light emitting polymer (LEP), organic electro polymer (OEL), or any other similar technology. For purposes of this chapter, a LED sign is not considered a form of changeable copy sign. Lot. See Parcel. Mansard roof means any roof that has an angle greater than 45 degrees and which derives part of its support from the building wall and is attached to, but not necessarily a part of, a low slope roof and which extends along the full length of the front building wall or three-quarters of the length of a side building wall. For purposes of this chapter, the term "low slope roof" means any roof with a pitch less than three inches rise per 12 inches horizontal. Marquee means any permanent roof-like structure projecting beyond a building or extending along and projecting beyond the wall of the building, generally designed and constructed to provide protection from the weather. Monument sign means a freestanding sign which forms a solid structure from the ground to the top of the sign. Nonconforming sign means a sign legally existing at the time of erection that could not be built under the terms of this chapter. Parcel means a unit of land as defined in a single deed recorded in the superior court deed records of the county. The description as specified in each recorded deed shall constitute a parcel of land for the purpose of this chapter. Provided, further, that two or more adjoining parcels in common ownership and which are physically unified by the existence of a common structure or development located thereon shall constitute and be considered as one parcel for the purpose of this Code. Person means and includes any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization, singular or plural, of any kind. Portable sign means any sign not permanently attached to the ground or other permanent structure, or a sign designed to be transported, including, but not limited to, signs designed to be transported by means of wheels, signs posted on the roofs or trucks beds of vehicles, signs converted to A-frames or T-frames; umbrellas used for advertising, and signs attached to or painted on vehicles parked and visible from the public right-of-way, unless said vehicle is used in the normal day-to-day operation of the business for purposes other than signage. Principal building means the building in which is conducted the principal use of the parcel on which it is located. Parcels with multiple principal uses may have multiple principal buildings, but storage buildings, garages, and other clearly accessory uses shall not be considered principal buildings. Projecting sign means any sign that is affixed at an angle or perpendicularly to the wall of any building in such a manner to read perpendicularly or at an angle to the wall on which it is mounted. Roof sign means a sign erected and constructed wholly on or over the roof of a building, supported by the roof structure, or extending vertically above the highest portion of the roof. Setback means the distance from the property line to the nearest plane of the applicable building, structure, or sign, measured perpendicularly to the property line. Shopping center means a group of retail stores, planned and developed for the safe upon which they are built and owned, managed or operated as a unit. Sign means and includes every device, frame, letter, figure, character, mark, plane, point, design, picture, logo, stroke, stripe, trademark or reading matter, which is used or intended to be used to attract attention or convey information when the same is placed out of doors in view of the general public. Also, the above, when near the inside surface of a window in such a way as to be in the view of the general public and used, or intended to be used, to attract attention or convey information to the public. Sign face means that portion of the surface of a sign structure where words, letters, figures, symbols, logos, fixtures, colors, or other design elements are or may be located in order to convey the message, idea, or intent for which the sign has been erected or placed. The sign face may be composed of two or more modules on the same surface that are separated or surrounded by portions of a sign structure not intended to contain any advertising message or idea and are purely structural or decorative in nature, including, but not limited to, channel letters. Sign height means the vertical distance to the highest point of a sign structure. The height is measured from the center line of the nearest adjacent street. Snipe sign means any sign which is attached in any way to a utility pole, fence post, or any other similar object located on public property. Special event sign means standard informational sign and/or spectacular signs and devices for a special use or event, such as, but not limited to, grand openings, seasonal sales, liquidations, going-out-of-business sales, fire sales, and giveaways or free promotions. Spectacular sign or device includes banners, beacons, balloons, streamers, and other attention-getting devices. Stanchion sign means a freestanding sign that is mounted on a pole or other vertical support such that the bottom of the sign face is more than six feet above the ground and there is no visual obstruction other than the vertical support between the ground and the bottom of the sign face. Standard informational sign means a sign with an area not greater than 4½ square feet, with a sign face for shortterm use, containing no reflective elements, flags, or projections, and which, when erected, stands at a height not greater than 2½ feet, and is mounted on a wooden stake or metal frame with a thickness or diameter not greater than 1½ inches. Streets and sidewalks means a strip of land or access way subject to vehicular traffic and/or pedestrian traffic that provides direct or indirect access to property including, but not limited to, alleys, avenues, boulevards, courts, drives, highways, lanes, places, roads, sidewalks, terraces, trails or other thoroughfares. Street frontage means the distance for which a lot line of a parcel adjoins a public or private street, from one lot line intersecting said street to the furthest distant lot line intersecting the same street. Suspended sign means a sign that is suspended from the underside of a horizontal plane surface and is supported by such surface. Tri-vision sign means a sign designed with a series of triangular slats that mechanically rotate in sequence with one another to show three different sign messages in rotation. For purposes of this chapter, a tri-vision sign is not a changeable copy sign. Wall sign means any sign that shall be affixed parallel to the wall or printed on the wall of any building in such a manner as to read parallel to the wall on which it is mounted; provided, however, said wall sign shall not project above the top of the wall or beyond the end of the building. Window sign means any sign placed inside or upon a window. (Code 1992, app. A, §§ 32(64)—(68), 97-2; Ord. No. 2009-5, § 97.2, 8-18-2009) Sec. 46-2. - Findings, purpose, and intent. (a) Findings of fact. The mayor and council find that: (1) Signs are a proper use of private property, are a means of personal free expression and a necessary component of a commercial environment. As such, signs are entitled to the protection of the law, however, an improperly regulated sign environment imposes health and safety dangers to the public. (2) The result of effective sign regulation will be to lessen hazardous conditions, confusion and visual clutter caused by the proliferation, improper placement, illumination and excessive height and size of signs which compete for the attention of pedestrians and vehicular traffic. (3) Proper regulation of signs is a necessary prerequisite to a peaceable, orderly and safely designed business environment. (4) Through proper regulation of signs, the aesthetic attractiveness and economic well-being of the city will be enhanced as a place to live, work and conduct business. (5) Concerns about aesthetic and safety issues as balanced with concerns about freedom of expression or speech are reasonably promoted in the city by the provisions of this chapter. (6) Some signage has a single targeted function and identification of such signage by description is impossible without referring to its function. For instance, address numerals are used for the sole purpose of providing addresses, which is of benefit to persons looking for those addresses and is essential to public safety personnel responding to emergencies. Signs at the entrances to subdivisions or major developments favor a similar purpose in enabling both the traveling public and emergency personnel to quickly locate entrances for the purpose of either visitation or responding to emergency calls. While such signage is referenced based upon the function it serves within the context of this chapter, the provisions of this chapter are unrelated to the content of the speech provided and allow maximum expressive potential to sign owners. Holiday decorations such as strings of light are not signs, but rather seasonal ornamentation not controlled by this chapter. (b) Purpose and intent. The purpose and intent of this chapter is: (1) To promote the mental and physical health, safety and welfare of the public by providing for the orderly and harmonious display of signs within the community; (2) To maintain and enhance the aesthetic environment by minimizing visual clutter, encouraging a positive visual environment, and avoiding the erection of displays which produce deleterious and injurious effects to adjacent properties and to the natural beauty of the environment; (3) To provide for the safety of the traveling public, both vehicular and pedestrian, by limiting distractions, hazards, and obstructions; (4) To maintain the city's ability to attract sources of economic development and growth and to aid in the identification of properties and enterprises for the convenience of the public; (5) To protect the area of the city designated for a centralized mixed-use pedestrian friendly downtown area from incompatible signage; (6) To encourage the effective use of signs as a means for communication in the city by allowing the maximum amount of expression or speech consistent with the compatibility of such expression or speech with other land uses and with the aesthetic and public health, safety and welfare concerns which the city is charged by law and the state constitution with preserving and protecting; (7) To enable the fair and consistent enforcement of these sign regulations while supporting the policies contained in the comprehensive plan pertaining to signage. (Code 1992, app. A, § 97-1; Ord. No. 2009-5, § 97.1, 8-18-2009) Sec. 46-3. - Computation of sign area. (a) Generally. Except as otherwise provided in subsections (b) and (c) of this section, the area of a sign face shall be computed by means of the smallest square, circle, rectangle, triangle, or combination thereof that will encompass the extreme limits of the writing, representation, emblem, color, or other display, together with any material or color forming an integral part of the background of the display or used to differentiate the sign from the backdrop or structure against which it is placed, but not including any supporting framework, bracing, or decorative fence or wall when such fence or wall otherwise meets other regulations of the city and is clearly incidental to the display itself. (b) Area of multifaced signs. The sign area of signs with more than one sign face shall be computed by adding together the area of all sign faces visible from any one point. When two sign faces are placed back to back, so that both faces are parallel, and when such sign faces are part of the same sign structure and are not more than 42 inches apart, the sign area shall be computed by the measurement of the larger of the two faces. (c) Area of monument signs. The computation of the sign area of a monument sign shall include the entire monument structure, as measured from the top to ground and side to side, upon which any words, letters, figures, symbols, logos, fixtures, colors or other design elements occur. (Code 1992, app. A, § 97-3; Ord. No. 2009-5, § 97.3, 8-18-2009) Sec. 46-4. - Prohibited signs. The following types of signs are prohibited: (1) If illuminated, signs containing, including, or illuminated by any flashing, intermittent, or moving lights except those contained in allowable changeable copy signs. (2) If illuminated, the illumination is such that it interferes with the effectiveness of, or obscures, an official traffic sign, device, or signal. (3) If illuminated, the illumination is not effectively shielded so as to prevent beams or rays of light from being directed at any portion of the traveled way and which are of such intensity or brilliance as to cause glare or to impair the vision of the driver of any motor vehicle, or which otherwise interfere with the operation of any motor vehicle. (4) Signs located so as to obscure, or otherwise interfere with the effectiveness of any official traffic sign, signal or device. (5) Signs located so as to obscure, or otherwise interfere with a motor vehicle operator's view of approaching, merging, or intersecting traffic. (6) Signs which obstruct any fire escape, any means of ingress, egress, or ventilation, or prevent free passage from one part of a roof to any other part thereto; signs attached in any manner to a fire escape. (7) Signs displaying any obscene message as obscenity is defined by U.S. Supreme Court decisions. (8) Roof signs, except those on the facings of mansard roofs. (9) Snipe signs. (10) Animated signs. (11) Signs, otherwise prohibited by this chapter, installed within a building in such a manner as to catch the attention of passersby outside the building. (12) Except for regulatory signs approved by appropriate federal, state or local authority, signs constructed, erected, or maintained closer than five feet to the edge of or on a public right-of-way as measured from the closest point of the sign structure as it relates to the legally defined boundary of such public right-of-way. (13) Signs utilizing LCD, LED or similar technology as any part of the sign face. (14) Signs utilizing tri-vision technology as any part of the sign face. (Code 1992, app. A, § 97-4; Ord. No. 2009-5, § 97.4, 8-18-2009) Sec. 46-5. - Compliance with technical codes; zoning. (a) All signs hereafter erected, replaced, reconstructed, repaired, altered, relocated or maintained within the city shall conform to the requirements of the standard building code, chapter 23, "Signs and Outdoor Displays," and to the requirements of the National Electrical Code, article 600, "Electrical Signs and Outline Lighting," both of which are adopted by the city. Where the provisions of the building or electrical code and this chapter conflict or overlap, the most stringent requirement shall prevail and be controlling. (b) All signs hereafter erected, replaced, reconstructed, repaired, altered or relocated within the city shall conform to the zoning ordinance of the city. In the event of conflict between the provisions of this chapter and chapter 66, pertaining to zoning, the most stringent requirements shall prevail and be controlling. (Code 1992, app. A, § 97-5; Ord. No. 2009-5, § 97.5, 8-18-2009) Sec. 46-6. - Maintenance of signs. Every sign, including those signs for which permits are required and those for which no permits or permit fees are required, shall be maintained in a safe, presentable and good structural condition at all times, including repair or replacement of defective parts, painting, repainting, cleaning and other acts required for the maintenance of the sign. (Code 1992, app. A, § 97-6; Ord. No. 2009-5, § 97.6, 8-18-2009) Sec. 46-7. - Erecting signs on private property. (a) No person within the city shall paste, print, nail, tack or otherwise fasten any card, banner, handbill, sign, poster or advertisement or notice of any kind, or cause the same to be done, on any private property, without the written consent of the owner of such property. (b) No person shall construct, erect, operate, use or maintain any sign without the written permission of the owner or other person in lawful possession or control of the property on which such structure or sign is located. (Code 1992, app. A, § 97-7; Ord. No. 2009-5, § 97.7, 8-18-2009) Sec. 46-8. - Erecting signs on public property. No person shall erect a sign on public property other than the governmental entity responsible for such property or public utility companies or contractors occupying or working on public property pursuant to government contract or franchise. (Code 1992, app. A, § 97-8.1; Ord. No. 2009-5, § 97.8, 8-18-2009) Sec. 46-9. - Regulation of signs on single-family residential parcels. All signs erected on single-family residential parcels in the city shall comply with the following provisions: (1) The aggregate sign area of all signs on a single-family residential parcel shall not exceed 16 square feet. (2) No sign shall be erected to a height greater than four feet. (3) Freestanding signs are allowed subject to the limitation of one per parcel. (4) Parcels may contain standard informational signs, subject to the aggregate sign area allowance, without a permit or fee, placed so that they are located entirely on private property. (5) In addition to any other signs authorized by this section, if such property is located at the entrance to any residential subdivision, then such property may contain no more than one permanent sign per entrance. Such signs may be lighted by single-flood, indirect lighting only, which may not be directed onto the street or vehicular traffic. (6) All signs erected shall be supported by independent means by use of a wooden stake or metal frame inserted directly into the ground. (7) Window signs are allowed subject to the limitation of one per single-family residential parcel, covering no more than 50 percent of the window. Window signs shall be included in the aggregate sign area for any property designed for residential use. (8) No sign erected on a single-family residential parcel may be illuminated except as allowed under subsection (5) of this section. (Code 1992, app. A, § 97-9; Ord. No. 2009-5, § 97.9, 8-18-2009) Sec. 46-10. - Regulation of signs in all other parcels. Signs erected on all properties zoned and intended for commercial, institutional, industrial and multifamily use shall comply with the following requirements: (1) Freestanding signs. Provisions regarding freestanding signs which include stanchion signs, monument signs, and joint signs are as follows: a. Number. Parcels fronting on one right-of-way shall be allowed no more than one freestanding sign per parcel. Parcels which front on more than one right-of-way shall be allowed one freestanding sign along each such right-of-way frontage, provided that no freestanding sign shall be erected along rights-of-way to or included in a buffer area for the protection of residentially zoned and developed districts. For purposes of this subsection, parcels front on a right-of-way when the lot line forms a common boundary with the edge of a public right-of-way and when driveway access is permitted and available from the public street onto the parcel along that common boundary; provided, that when an exterior wall of the primary building on the parcel is used or intended to be used as the rear or back of the structure and contains only service entrances, driveways and/or loading zone access, the lot line along that side of the building shall not be considered as fronting on a right-of-way. b. Joint signs. Multiple businesses on a single parcel shall share the permitted number of freestanding signs under subsection (1)a of this section as joint signs. c. Sign face limits for single businesses. For single businesses on parcels of ten acres or more in size, the maximum sign face shall be 300 square feet. For single businesses on parcels of three acres or more in size, but less than ten acres in size, the maximum sign face shall be 160 square feet. For single businesses on parcels of less than three acres in size, the maximum sign face shall be 130 square feet. d. Sign face limits for joint signs. The maximum sign face for joint signs on parcels of ten acres or more in size shall be 300 square feet. The maximum sign face for joint signs on parcels of three acres or more, but less than ten acres in size, shall be 220 square feet. The maximum sign face of joint signs on parcels of less than three acres in size shall be 160 square feet. e. Height. No freestanding, joint or stanchion sign shall be erected to a height of more than 22 feet, provided that shopping centers and business parks covering ten acres or more may erect such signs to a height of 30 feet. Monument signs shall not exceed six feet in height nor ten feet in length. All freestanding signs shall be surrounded by protective curbing and shall be placed in a landscaped area. None shall be permitted to encroach in a parking area to such extent that the remaining parking spaces fail to meet the standards of chapter 66 regarding off-street parking. (2) Wall signs. a. Number. Each business premises shall be allowed one wall sign; provided that business premises facing more than one right-of-way shall be allowed a wall sign on each building side facing a right-of-way when an exterior wall of the business premises is approximately parallel to a public right-of-way from which driveway access is permitted to that business; provided that exterior walls of business premises used or intended to be used as the rear or back of a structure and containing only service entrances, driveway and/or loading zone access shall not be considered to face a right-of-way. For purposes of this subsection the term "business premises" means an entity holding fee simple title to the property or a written lease from the building owner. b. Sign face limit. The maximum sign face shall be 15 percent of the business's front facade, provided that any business may erect a wall sign of at least six square feet. No wall sign shall exceed 220 square feet of sign face. c. Multiple businesses. For multiple businesses conducted on the same parcel under unified ownership or management, occupying separate structures and for which separate business licenses have been obtained, wall signs shall be erected only on the primary structure utilized by the licensed business. d. Gas stations . In the case of gas stations, a wall sign may be included on the canopy over the pump islands. (3) Changeable copy signs. Changeable copy signs are permitted in conjunction with freestanding signs, wall signs, and joint signs so long as the changeable copy portion of the sign face does not exceed 60 percent of the overall sign face of the freestanding or wall signs or 30 percent of the overall sign face of a joint sign; and provided that the total sign face does not exceed the size limitations imposed elsewhere by this Code. (4) Window signs. Window signs may be displayed only inside of the window of the business or organization advertising the products or events in such sign; and the display area shall not exceed 50 percent of the window surface. (5) Billboards. a. Number. In lieu of other freestanding signs any property located in a commercial or industrial district may contain one billboard per platted lot. No billboard shall be placed on any lot that contains any freestanding sign. b. Location. No billboards shall be located within 500 feet of another existing billboard. Billboards shall be erected no further than 100 feet from the right-of-way line of any state or federal highway. No billboard shall be located within 500 feet of single-family residentially zoned parcels and/or parcels designated for single-family residential use. No billboard shall be located within 1,500 feet in any direction of a public park, public playground, public recreational area, school, public forest, scenic area or cemetery. c. Sign face limit. No billboard sign face shall exceed 310 square feet. d. Height. Billboards may be erected to a height of no more than 22 feet above the grade of the highway. No billboard shall exceed 30 feet in length and the bottom coping of the sign shall be a minimum of ten feet above ground level. e. Setback. All portions of a sign face and support members of any billboard shall be setback at least 50 feet from all buildings, structures, property lines, and rights-of-way. f. Illumination. All illuminated billboards shall use base-mounted fluorescent or mercury vapor lights and shall be activated by photoelectric cells. Additional lighting, including, but not limited to, neon, animation and running lights, is prohibited. g. Extrusions prohibited. Extrusions beyond the sign face of any billboard, excluding aprons, are prohibited. h. Visible face. Billboards shall not contain more than one face visible from the same direction on the main traveled way. Double-faced, back-to-back constructed signs shall, for the purpose of determining compliance with size and space limitations, be considered as one sign. i. Stacking prohibited. No billboard shall be stacked one above the other and there shall be no V-type sign structures, only single-pole, back-to-back structures shall be allowed. The sign owner shall be responsible for maintaining the sign and ensuring that no litter accumulates from posting or deterioration of any sign. j. Obscuring view of motor vehicle operator. No billboard shall be located so as to obscure or otherwise interfere with a motor vehicle operator's view of approaching, merging, or intersecting traffic. k. Insurance required. No person shall engage within the corporate limits of the city in the business of erecting or maintaining billboards under this chapter until after such persons shall have filed with the city clerk evidence of liability insurance coverage of: $50,000.00 property damage, $100,000.00 personal injury to any one person and $200,000.00 for personal injury growing out of any one occurrence. Such liability insurance will save and keep the city, and all of its officials, employees and agents, harmless from all damages, liabilities, losses or judgments resulting by reason of the erection or maintenance of any such sign, and of any injury to persons or damages to property resulting therefrom. (6) Bench signs. a. Location. Bench signs shall be allowed only along arterial streets within the city as defined in this subsection, and in areas with sidewalks. For purposes of this subsection, arterial streets shall include N. Houston Lake Road, Carl Vinson Parkway, Gunn Road, and U.S. Highway 41. Bench signs shall be allowed only in commercial and industrial zoned districts. b. Number. Only one bench sign shall be permitted and allowed per city block. (7) Banners. a. Number. No more than one banner may be displayed on a parcel at any one time. b. Size. Banners shall not exceed three feet by eight feet in size. c. Duration. Banners are permitted for a maximum of 15 consecutive days no more than once per calendar quarter at any one location. All banners require a permit. All banners must be removed by the expiration date on the permit. d. Mounting. Banners must be mounted on the building front and flush with the building surface. (8) Special event signs. a. Permit required. Prior to any such special event or use and the erection of such special event signs, an application shall be filed with the enforcement officer as detailed in section 46-11. The maximum number of temporary permits to be issued to a single business location or parcel shall be four per year for a period of time not to exceed 15 days for each issuance. A minimum of 30 days shall elapse between special event periods. b. Size. The maximum size allowed for all special event signs and devices per parcel shall be 150 square feet. c. Removal. Failure to remove special event signs within the time frames required shall result in forfeiture of one permit period for each day the special event sign remains in violation, up to a maximum of four periods or one year. Such forfeiture shall be in addition to other penalties provided for violation in this Code. All special event signs must comply with all other applicable provisions of this chapter. (9) Incidental signs. Incidental signs may be erected at driveway entrances and exits and parking lots without regard to limitations on numbers of signs which are otherwise applicable. (Code 1992, app. A, § 97-10; Ord. No. 2009-5, § 97.10, 8-18-2009) Sec. 46-11. - Permit required; procedures. (a) Unless specifically exempted from obtaining a permit under the provisions of this chapter, no person shall erect, construct, replace, relocate or structurally alter any sign within the city without first obtaining a sign permit from the city. (b) Applications for permits shall be made upon forms provided by the city and shall contain or have attached thereto the following information: (1) Name, address and telephone number of the applicant. (2) Tax parcel ID and address of building, structure, or parcel to which or upon which the sign is to be attached or erected.
